Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Evaluation of Sedimentary Lipid Hydrogen Isotopes as an Arctic Precipitation Proxy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will characterize the distribution and hydrogen isotopic composition of plant biomarkers in lake sediments and modern plants to reconstruct past hydroclimate environments in the Arctic. By inferring the isotopic composition of past precipitation patterns and lake waters, this research will facilitate better modeling of the impacts of environmental change on Arctic ecosystems. Improved reconstruction of past hydroclimates will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the Arctic's atmospheric circulation responses to amplified thermal configurations. The project promises a significant STEM education component led by three early-career women that includes the engagement of several undergraduate students in research activities. In addition, the doctoral student will work with the PI on workshops for K-12 STEM teachers from Chicago and Evanston public schools to incorporate current scientific information into their educational materials. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Existing paleoclimate records provide unique perspectives on how climate related to the hydrologic cycle varied temporally over the Arctic. However, there presently are insufficient data samples and inadequately calibrated proxies to confidently assess changes in hydroclimate. To facilitate improved reconstructions of past hydroclimate environments, the doctoral student will develop new methodologies for characterizing the distributions and hydrogen isotopic values of modern lipids in lake sediments and modern plants along an extensive latitudinal and climatic transect. Gas chromatography and mass spectrometry will be used on lake sediments cores to derive a dataset of plant biomarkers and their correlates (alkanes and acids.) Sedimentary leaf wax and aquatic plant lipid hydrogen isotopes will be measured and used to infer source water hydrogen isotopes by applying a fractionation correction. By answering fundamental questions about the characterization of lipid biomarkers and the relationship between lipid biomarkers and source water, the research will advance the broader application of using hydrogen lipid biomarkers as a paleohydrologic proxy in sedimentary archives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant waxes are an important proxy for reconstructing past precipitation through geologic time via the hydrogen isotope ratios of wax compounds preserved in sediments. The relationship between the isotopic composition of plant waxes and their environmental water has been demonstrated for mid-low latitudes but was largely untested for plants in the Arctic. This presented a challenge for using this tool in a quantitative manner across the Arctic to reconstruct past precipitation.

In this study, we measured the hydrogen isotope composition of sedimentary plant waxes (wax compounds preserved in lake sediments) from 22 lakes along a large latitudinal and climatic gradient in Greenland to improve understanding of this important paleo-precipitation proxy. We tested the correlation between the hydrogen isotopic composition of plant wax compounds (n-alkanes, n-alkanoic acids) and local environmental water (precipitation, lake water). We also measured the carbon isotopic composition of waxes to assess the source of wax compounds into the sedimentary record (C3 vs. C4 plants). A resulting undergraduate project also examined the relationship between the waxes of modern local plants and modern sedimentary waxes in a small watershed, and constructed a downcore record using hydrogen and carbon isotopes of plant waxes that extends through the last ~3000 years.

We find that some sedimentary wax compounds in the Arctic demonstrate a strong relationship to summer growth season water that can be used to infer the hydrogen isotope ratios of paleo-precipitation from the hydrogen isotope ratios of sedimentary wax compounds in lakes across the Arctic. This provides new potential to reconstruct the hydrogen isotopic composition of summer precipitation across Arctic regions, which can provide new insight into moisture source, amount, and hydrologic balance through time. As part of this research, we also synthesized all published sedimentary plant wax data (C29 n-alkanes, C28 n-alkanoic acids) from all regions of the globe, and we find that the relationship between sedimentary plant waxes in Greenland is largely consistent with the relationship observed in mid-low latitudes. These findings provide evidence that this tool can be used across the globe, and update the quantitative relationship between hydrogen isotopes of plant wax compounds and local precipitation globally. 

Broader impacts of this project include research training of a female Ph.D. student and female undergraduate student in organic geochemistry and polar geoscience, contributions by the PhD student and lead PI to science communication training for graduate students, and outreach to high school science teachers. The findings of this research have been presented at multiple conferences and will be submitted to scientific journals.
